subject: Marketing
title: Syllable Pricing
description: A micro-lesson that makes Syllable Pricing usable.

hook.text: People perceive prices with fewer syllables as cheaper‚Äîeven when the amount is the same.

buildup.text: Your brain subvocally reads prices. More syllables feel like a bigger number.

discovery.text: $27.82 has seven syllables. $28.00 has four. The shorter one feels smaller.

twist.text: Removing the cents from a menu price makes everything feel more affordable.

climax.text: Fine restaurants use '$28' not '$28.00' because fewer syllables signal effortless luxury.

quiz.question: How do syllables in a price affect perception?
options: More syllables make prices feel larger
Syllables have no effect on price perception
Fewer syllables make prices feel more expensive
